185908903.review:
"It's Fallout 1/2 with Metro 2033 themes."

This is absolutely worth your time if you can accept the hand-drawn sprites (instead of 3D) and some quality-of-life limitations with quests, inventory, and fast-travel.  (And they're no [i]worse[/i] than Fallout 1/2 were.)

This is almost a one-man project and the amount of content in here is fantastic - on par with MGS:V and AssCreed:Oddysey.
The [b]worldbuilding is great[/b].
The combat is good.
The inventory management is... not great.  It could definitely do with things like "sort by weight".  At least it's hard to accidentally lose a quest-only item.
The [b]quest management is inadequate[/b] by modern standards.  You will repeatedly say "WTF am I supposed to do now?"  You will need to read the wiki or pay close attention to one-time quest-giver dialogue, because the quest screen won't always give explicit directions.  It is *very* easy to find the quest item in a locker and not realize it, because the quest screen doesn't update with "you've got X, now take it back to NPC Y".  It only has "todo: X for NPC Y" and "done: you got X for NPC Y".
(It has an excellent wiki, which is enough to get you out of most jams.)
The auto-map is a big help except in big cities.  SGS has per-floor maps, but Core City and University don't.
You cannot fast-travel to or from arbitrary places (a la Morrowind COC command), instead you must walk to a fast-travel point (e.g. a station) and then travel to another point on the same travel network.  Combined with the poor quest stages, this can make backtracking frustrating, but it's not a show-stopper (a la Morrowind without console commands).
There are a couple of quests where you can lock yourself into an undesirable questline without realizing it.  In particular, [spoiler]negotiating a moderate solution to the Train Heist locks you into the police genocide path for police-vs-slaves[/spoiler].

Oh, also, anything that improves your movement speed (tabi boots, faster DLC jetski) is worth having just for faster backtracking / non-fast travel.  You can also improve effective speed by changing run time (Ctrl+MouseUp) and zooming out (Shift+MouseDown, disabled in options menu by default).

I avoided buying this game for a long time because I expected to bounce off the old-style graphics. After a couple of hours I didn't notice that at all.
I think Encased has better graphics, and Atom RPG / Trudograd has better Slav bleakness, but UnderRail is better at most everything else.  Play all three!

https://store.steampowered.com/app/921800/Encased_A_SciFi_PostApocalyptic_RPG/
https://store.steampowered.com/app/552620/ATOM_RPG_Postapocalyptic_indie_game/

PS: you can become a Cave Jedi about five minutes into the game (or anytime after that) by taking a magic pill.  I never actually tried this.  There are a couple of enemies that can only be hurt by Jedi, but you can run/sneak around them with a little save-scumming.  I feel like the "be a Cave Jedi?" option would have worked better either during character creation, or (as in KOTOR) teased until the end of Act I (when you [spoiler]clear the rail lines with the Junkyard MacGuffin[/spoiler]).

Also initial game start is a little slow, but quickload is very fast, which is a good trade-off.

185658550.review:
Wrote this with just under 90 hours on the clock. Restarted a few times in the early stages of the game, but am ultimately over it after reaching level 18 and spending most of the time exploring.
Still don't feel like I've made much progress, despite this, given the expansive scope of the game.
Unless you're a die-hard Fallout 1/2 fan, it really isn't worth getting into.

-----
Cons
-----
Meta save scumming simulator. You will likely spend 60% of the game save scumming.

The game is an unforgiving time sink.
Power build or die. Either spend a bunch of time deciding which build to use specifically beforehand by looking up existing builds online, or don't play at all.
Misplaced a skill point or perk? Too bad. Reload or start an entirely new game.

You can look forward to investing an hour into damn near every battle - save scumming like you have nothing better to play.

You'll be micro managing every little thing with no backup or party mechanics whatsoever. The fact that you are sent out to deal with absolutely everything on your own is utter, laughable bollocks.

You'll be spamming a lot of grenades (and save scumming when you miss).
Unless your build allows you to put points into the Throwing skill, you'll be lobbing them 20 meters in the damn-near opposite direction as if you have cerebral palsy.

The inventory system is a pain in the ass.
Managing item weight is a massive hindrance. Given the scope of the areas to traverse, and lack of meaningful fast travel aside from boats, you'll be spending half of the game encumbered while you ferry loot around.

Most of the loot you'll find is garbage that you won't be able to use unless your build makes use of the crafting skills.

The traders are anal-retentive with regards to what they will or will not purchase from you, and how many of those desired items you can actually sell. It renders most of that loot-ferrying and hoarding as meaningless. I understand the need to limit the player's purchasing power so as to keep economy relevant, but you don't have a lot of good purchase options anyway.

Unless you've played before and know where everything is and exactly what you're doing, or you're following a walkthrough (lame), you'll have to spend probably 100+ hours to get anywhere meaningful in the game.

The old-school isometric style of the game, as nostalgic as it is, can make navigation and clicking on things a hassle unless you're holding tab like 60% of the time.

You can't speed up the game while even lightly encumbered. Gotta keep the player moving at a snails' pace to boost them play time numbers.

The initiative system is stupid. If you are in stealth mode, and attack an enemy despite not having been spotted at all on approach, there's every likelihood that your attack is nixed and they get their turns first (more opportunities for save scumming, yay!).  You can't use burst/automatic gunfire from out of stealth, either.

The quests are boring.

The game is, ultimately, boring.

-----
Pros
-----
Extensive campaign
Lots of hand-placed detail
The dialogue is decent
In-depth item crafting system
Lots of items
Lots of build options
Somewhat modernized old-school isometric style

いわゆるポストアポカリプスもの。
Fallout1～2風の見下ろし型の探索と戦闘の難易度の高いゲーム。

Falloutとは違って地上に人は住めないらしい。
なぜかわからないけど、核戦争が原因とかは明言されてなかった気がする。
地下鉄や駅を基点にした社会が構築されてる点は、METROのほうが近いかも。

全くかかわりのなかった地域や団体の後日談がでてきて「こんな連中いたんか…」ってなった。

完全に続編に続く終わり方をしてるなと思ったら、2は制作中らしく、ちょうどゲームプレイ映像が公開されたところだった。（2024/12）

ゲームの操作性は個人的にはかなりいまいち。
特に微妙だったのが、オブジェクトのハイライトが、Altキー押しっぱなしなところ。
トグルにしてくれればいいのに、押してる間だけハイライトされるので、ほぼ常にAltキー押してる必要があって鬱陶しい。
（最終的に、Alt押しっぱなしになるマクロ組んで使ってた）

そのほかは、インベントリもいまいち。
ソートが1種類しかないので、装備品の選定とかするのめんどい。

あと、有志による日本語化があるのだけど、ほぼ機械翻訳で何言ってるか伝わらないところが多々あり、ストーリーにのめりこめなかった。
そもそも日本語化がないとプレイ自体できなかったので、完全に自分の英語力不足が原因ではありますが…

戦闘はまじで難易度高い。
下手なビルドで進めると、わりとシンプルに詰む。
レベル上限も25と低めなので、レベルを上げて物理で殴ることはできない。
アイテムでなんとかするのか？と思っても手榴弾の類はクールタイムが4ターンとかあるので連続で投げられないし「投げ」スキルを取得してないと命中率が割とゴミ。
トラップ設置にはクールタイムないと思うけど「罠」スキルが高くないと強い罠使えないし、戦闘中はQuick Tinkeringというfeat（能力）を取得しないと使えないし、このfeatは5ターンのクールタイムがあるので、結局連続で罠置けない。
Normalでクリアしたけど、HardとかDOMINATINGはどうやってクリアすんのか…

[h3]ビジュアル[/h3]
ビジュアルについては、ぶっちゃけしょぼい。
まあ、あえてなのだろうけど、とてもレトロ。
慣れるとこれはこれで味がある、と思えなくもない。

[h3]まとめ[/h3]
舞台設定や雰囲気はとても好き。

ただ、ゲームシステムは正直ほめられたものじゃない。
少なくても人を選ぶと思う。

エンディングを見る限り、クリアしてないクエストとかたくさん残ってそうだけど、再度プレイする気にはなれない。

[h1] ★☆☆[/h1]

A small disclaimer, my current game time amounts to 87 hours on GOG version, but honestly, it feels like way more. I have completed the main story and Expedition, while Heavy Duty is saved for another time, partly because I was really invested in the main story and wanted to see the ending.

So, I can't help but sing praises to this game as it is a marvel and a breath of fresh air. Narratively, it is amazing. It presents a very interesting world and likable characters while at the same time never drowning in pointless text. It all feels very real and believable, like in a sense, it is something you can picture and somethig you can enjoy without any dissoance. No ass pulls, no characters staying stupid crap or wasting air while patronizing the player. The writing is light, very smooth and a complete joy to read. It doesn't waste time and has no pointless dialogue. When I jumped into it I was completely hooked on and kept playing for days. It is one of those games where it is [i]fun[/i] to read item descriptions and computer messages. They story these bits of lore build syncs beautifully.

I also HAVE to mention the atmosphere, as it is probably the most atmospheric game I've played in a long time. There were precise moments when background music, dialogue and visuals all created an amazing episodes when you can just see your character in this world, plotting and doing things. Mine was when [spoiler] I was talking with Blaine about Junkyard [/spoiler]. The music is just done right and hits amazingly well in certain moments. There is just so much soul here. I can't praise Stygs enough for this, even though [spoiler]the ending is very anticlimatic and raises more questions than it gives you answers [/spoiler].

Combat system is pretty straight forward and quick to get a hang of, despite initially looking complicated. A build is [i]really[/i] recommended for a better experience. There is some space to wiggle, but it is best to know what you are getting. You'll have to choose your combat playstyle and won't be able to effectively use every weapon.

It has some replayability value for some, but be advised, you can sink days here.

If you like hardcore RPGs with a ton of grind, UnderRail is the real deal. It's like if Fallout 1 and 2 had a baby with a brutal difficulty curve and no hand-holding. You’re dropped into this underground world where you gotta fend for yourself, and trust me, it’s not gonna be easy. Every decision counts, and the game doesn’t care if you’re ready for it – it just throws you in the deep end.

The combat? Chef’s kiss – turn-based, but the enemies are relentless and won’t hesitate to wreck you. You gotta think 3 steps ahead, or you’re done. And the skill system is so deep it’s like drowning in options, but once you get the hang of it, it’s sick. You’re basically building your character for the apocalypse.

Story’s kinda wild too, lots of factions, moral choices, and weird stuff happening in the tunnels. But don’t expect a hand-holding experience – if you miss a quest or screw something up, you’re just gonna have to live with it.

The world? Dark, gritty, and oh-so atmospheric. It really nails the whole "life underground sucks" vibe. Graphics are old-school, but that’s part of the charm. Plus, it runs like butter, even on my toaster of a PC.

Bottom line: UnderRail isn’t for the faint-hearted. If you’re into tough-as-nails RPGs that make you feel like you earned every win, this is your game. But yeah, prepare to die a lot. Like, a lot. But it’s worth it, trust me.

探索地下世界的地牢探险类RPG。

《Underrail》的世界是一个地下的地铁站、地道、地底湖泊的联合体。数百年前的一场灾害让人们离开地表，住到地下。此后社会日渐礼崩乐坏，如今人们住在各个地铁站里，各自为政。主角作为其中一个地铁站的新人，将卷入一场搅动整个地下的巨大事件。

相比于《辐射》、《The age of decadence》这些注重剧情的同类等角视角游戏，《Underrail》的游戏重心在于探索。很多时候你会需要探索一些灾前文明留下的建筑，从中发掘灾前文明的历史故事。

战斗方面，是很经典的桌游式回合制战斗。绝大多数时候是一对多的战斗。群体控制（crowd control）十分重要，不然战斗会十分困难。习惯了之后，战斗会变得很公式化。当然也有人就喜欢这种桌游机制，喜欢研究计算各种数值，在战斗开始之前就能计算出自己胜率多大。

你要问我推不推荐，我只能说60%推荐。虽然我游戏时长很长，但其中有相当部分时间是在跑图和买卖东西。建议用 Cheat Engine 开启无限背包空间，能省去很多背包管理的时间。要购买的话，一定要加上Expedition DLC。建议边看游戏wiki边玩，这样能避免错过能了解更多剧情的任务。

最后，附上我写的一个角色创建指南：https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=3390183677 。 想玩高智力角色的人可以参考。
